title: Annotation Quickstart
text:
Your Task
This page is a quick reference for the LatinCy annotation review process. Detailed guidelines for each topic are in preparation and will be published as additional chapters.
You are reviewing model output ‚Äî the LatinCy pipeline has already analyzed each text, and your job is to check and correct its predictions. Each passage is presented in a spreadsheet with the following columns:
It will take time to get used to reading the Latin in this word-by-word fashion, but after a few sentences you should begin to develop some strategies and notice patterns.

title: Annotation Quickstart
text:
Column
What it contains
Your action




token

Check and correct if needed

title: Annotation Quickstart
text:
Lemma
The lemma is the dictionary headword. It should match whatever appears in the passage vocabulary.
Quick rules:

Nouns: nominative singular ‚Äî homo, civitas, rex
Adjectives: nominative singular masculine ‚Äî bonus, omnis, felix
Verbs: first person singular present indicative ‚Äî amo, sum, fero, dico
Pronouns: citation form varies ‚Äî qui, sui, ego, hic
Prepositions: fuller form ‚Äî ab (not a), ex (not e)







TipCommon errors to watch for




Adjectives lemmatized as neuter (omne) or plural (omnes) instead of masculine singular (omnis)
Deponent verbs lemmatized as active
Prepositions shortened (a instead of ab)



Full lemmatization guidelines forthcoming.

title: Annotation Quickstart
text:
UPOS (Part of Speech)
The UPOS column contains one of the following 17 tags:








Tag
Description
Examples




ADJ
Adjective
bonus, omnis, magnus


ADP
Adposition (preposition)
in, ad, de, cum, per


ADV
Adverb
non, iam, semper, bene


AUX
Auxiliary verb (for our purposes, just sum)
est, sunt, erat


CCONJ
Coordinating conjunction
et, sed, atque, vel


DET
Determiner
hic, ille, iste, omnis (when modifying a noun)


INTJ
Interjection
o, ecce, eheu


NOUN
Noun
vir, urbs, virtus, bellum


NUM
Numeral
unus, duo, tres, centum


PART
Particle
autem, enim, igitur, quidem


PRON
Pronoun
qui, ego, se, quis


PROPN
Proper noun
Caesar, Roma, Gallia


PUNCT
Punctuation
. , ; :


SCONJ
Subordinating conjunction
ut, cum, si, quod, quia


SYM
Symbol
‚Ä† (crux in charters), %


VERB
Verb (including infinitives and participles)
dicit, fecit, dicere, dictus


X
Other (foreign words, typos)
œáŒ±·øñœÅŒµ, shalom









NoteKey distinctions




PART vs.¬†CCONJ: Discourse particles like autem, enim, igitur are PART (not CCONJ). Coordinating conjunctions join clauses or phrases: et, sed, atque.
NOUN vs.¬†PROPN: Common nouns (rex, consul) are NOUN. Specific names (Caesar, Roma) are PROPN.



Full POS tagging guidelines forthcoming.

title: Annotation Quickstart
text:
Morphological Features
The feats column contains morphological features separated by |. The model predicts these; you should verify the key features for each word class.

Nouns, Adjectives, Pronouns, Determiners
These should have Gender, Number, and Case:



Feature
Values




Gender
Fem, Masc, Neut


Number
Sing, Plur


Case
Nom, Gen, Dat, Acc, Abl, Voc (also Loc rarely)



Example: virtutis ‚Üí Case=Gen|Gender=Fem|Number=Sing


Verbs
These should have Person, Number, Tense, Aspect, Mood, Voice, and VerbForm:







Feature
Values




Person
1, 2, 3


Number
Sing, Plur


Tense
Pres, Past, Fut, Pqp (pluperfect)


Aspect
Perf (perfective), Imp (imperfective)


Mood
Ind, Sub (subjunctive), Imp (imperative)


Voice
Act, Pass


VerbForm
Fin (finite), Inf (infinitive), Part (participle), Ger (gerund), Gdv (gerundive), Sup (supine)



Example: scripsit ‚Üí Aspect=Perf|Mood=Ind|Number=Sing|Person=3|Tense=Past|VerbForm=Fin|Voice=Act






NoteTense and Aspect



UD uses Tense=Past for all past tenses. The Aspect feature distinguishes them:

scripsit (perfect): Tense=Past|Aspect=Perf
scribebat (imperfect): Tense=Past|Aspect=Imp
scripserat (pluperfect): Tense=Pqp|Aspect=Perf









TipWhat to check



Focus on the features most likely to be wrong:

Case: The model sometimes confuses nominative/accusative for neuter nouns, or nominative/vocative
Tense/Aspect: Past perfective (scripsit) vs.¬†past imperfective (scribebat)
Mood: Indicative vs.¬†subjunctive
Voice: Active vs.¬†passive, especially for deponent verbs

title: Annotation Quickstart
text:
Dependency Relations
For now, you only need to check two dependency labels:

ROOT
The main verb of each sentence should be labeled ROOT. Every sentence has exactly one ROOT.
Poeta        carmen       scripsit.
nsubj        obj          ROOT
"The poet    a poem       wrote."






WarningCopular sentences



In copular sentences, the predicate (not sum) is the ROOT:
Cicero       consul       est.
nsubj        ROOT         cop
"Cicero      consul       is."
Here consul is the ROOT because it is the predicate nominal. est is labeled cop (copula).




nsubj
The subject of the main verb should be labeled nsubj (nominal subject). Look for the nominative noun or pronoun that performs the action.
Rex          exercitum    duxit.
nsubj        obj          ROOT
"The king    the army     led."
Not every sentence has an explicit subject ‚Äî Latin often drops the pronoun (‚Äúpro-drop‚Äù):
Venit.
ROOT
"(He/she) came."
Full dependency parsing guidelines forthcoming.

title: Annotation Quickstart
text:
Named Entity Types
Check whether names referring to specific people, places, or groups are correctly labeled with one of three entity types:

PERSON
Named individuals, deities, and specific mythological groups.



Tag
Not tagged




Caesar (PERSON)
consul (title, not a name)


Venus (PERSON)
dea (common noun)


Ceres (PERSON)
Cerealia (derived adjective)


Musae (PERSON)
deae (common noun)





LOC
Locations ‚Äî cities, regions, rivers, mountains, any named place.



Tag
Not tagged




Roma (LOC)
urbs (common noun)


Tiberis (LOC)
flumen (common noun)


Alpes (LOC)
montes (common noun)





NORP
Nationalities or religious or political groups. This includes both noun and adjective forms.



Tag
Not tagged




Romani (NORP)
cives (common noun)


Troianus (NORP, adjective form)
milites (common noun)


Christiani (NORP)
sacerdotes (common noun)









NoteNORP is used somewhat anachronistically



In the modern NLP context it stands for ‚ÄúNationalities or religious or political groups.‚Äù We apply it to ancient groups of people by analogy.


Full NER guidelines forthcoming.

title: Annotation Quickstart
text:
Quick Checklist
When reviewing a passage:

Read through the Latin text to understand the passage
Scan the lemma column ‚Äî do headwords match what you see in the vocabulary?
Scan the upos column ‚Äî are content words (NOUN, VERB, ADJ) labeled correctly?
Scan the feats column ‚Äî for nouns/adjectives, check gender/number/case; for verbs, check person/number/tense/aspect/mood/voice
Find the ROOT ‚Äî is the main verb labeled ROOT?
Find the nsubj ‚Äî is the subject of that verb labeled nsubj?
Scan for names ‚Äî are people, places, and groups labeled PERSON, LOC, or NORP?
Correct errors in the designated cells only
